awd_abstract_narration: The goal of the STEM for Education (STEM-E) Scholarship Program at Rutgers University is to recruit, retain, and maintain a community of engineers and physicists who are dedicated to teaching in high-needs school districts. Intellectual Merit is encompassed in an overarching theme of "STEM for Humanity" and the program (1) blends the physics and engineering undergraduate programs with the existing graduate physics and mathematics teacher preparation programs, (2) strengthens the focus on teaching physics and mathematics to students in high-needs districts, (3) includes an e-mentoring network between pre- and in-service teachers, and (4) infuses seminars that illustrate the impact of STEM on society.  Fifteen STEM-E scholars are being prepared to graduate ready to teach in high-needs K-12 math and science classrooms with strong pedagogical content knowledge and deep understanding of the importance of STEM professionals. Additionally, the program offers long-term continuing professional development to ensure the success of new teachers. Broader Impacts are achieved in that STEM-E scholars will be the nation's leading educational change agents serving in high-need school districts as highly qualified math and science teachers who integrate engineering into their math and physics courses. A mixed-method evaluation plan includes formative and summative assessment of program goals and components. Results are disseminated through the program's website and presentations at conferences.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the STEM for Education (STEM-E) Scholarship Program at Rutgers University were to recruit, retain, and graduate a community of engineers and physicists who are dedicated to teaching physics, mathematics and engineering in high-needs, K-12 school districts. With an overarching theme of "STEM for Humanity?, the implemented program enhanced Rutgers existing engineering and physics undergraduate programs, as well as the graduate programs in mathematics and physical science education in the Graduate School of Education (GSE) that prepared high school teachers of mathematics and physics. Specifically, STEM-E blended the physics and engineering undergraduate programs with the existing graduate teacher preparation programs, strengthening the focus on teaching physics and mathematics to students in high-needs districts and infused these programs with seminars that illustrated the great impact STEM has on society. The STEM-E Scholars graduated ready to teach in high-needs K-12 math and science classrooms with strong pedagogical content knowledge and deep understanding of the importance of STEM professionals.

The STEM-E Scholarship Program was a collaborative partnership among the Rutgers Graduate School of Education, the School of Engineering and the Department of Physics and Astronomy, along with 13 high needs NJ Public Schools that aimed to prepare a diverse community of future K-12 teachers by: 

 Awarding a scholarship in the amount of $15,000 per year to a total of 19 engineering and physics students who will pursue teacher certification and teach in a high-needs school district (minimum of 2 years teaching for each year awarded scholarship); 

 Providing meaningful opportunities that enhance Scholars' content and pedagogical content knowledge to include coursework, early teaching experiences and fieldwork at local school districts;

 Integrating the theme of ?STEM for Humanity? by offering seminars and workshops engaging scholars in meaningful discussions on how science, technology, engineering, and mathematics impact society and ethical issues; 

 Establishing an e-mentor network between in-service teachers and pre-service Scholars; 

 Recruiting and retaining Scholars through an internship program with pre-college engineering programs administered by the Office of Student Access & Inclusion; and

 Developing and building upon former partnerships with NSF-funded programs to leverage resources, such as engaging Scholars in the Rutgers University Research Experience for Teachers in Engineering (RU RET-E) summer and academic year program.

Intellectual Merit

The concluding project answered the national call to recruit and train highly qualified math and science teachers by expanding the traditional pool of recruits to engineering students. The program?s design leveraged partnerships among the School of Engineering, Graduate School of Education, and Department of Physics and Astronomy at Rutgers University, as well as with thirteen NJ Public Schools. The innovative approach included integrating a STEM for Humanity theme that introduced Scholars? to the impact STEM professionals have on our society, relevant literature and research on high-needs schools, and experience in hands-on projects for the K-12 classroom. Lastly, the program offered a model for long-term continued professional development to ensure the success of new teachers. 

Broader Impacts

STEM-E provided a unique model that affords physics and engineering majors the opportunity to enhance their educational experience and expand their professional horizon. Specifically, these scholars are the nation?s leading educational change agents serving in high needs K-12 school districts as highly qualified math and science teachers. They will continue to provide K-12 students with access to an excellent education, mentoring and help K-12 teachers bring engineering into math and physics courses.   

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/22/2023
Modified by: Michael Brown
